results.title: The Way of the Exploding Fist  for Commodore 64
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette and cover in a plastic cassette case
results.brief_description:
‘The Way of the Exploding Fist’ was one of Beam Software’s best-selling games, and reached number one in Europe. It was one of the first ‘beat-‘em-up’ games for the home computer and the first multi-move beat em up. Jordan Mechner’s “Karateka”(1984) which came out just before “The Way of the Exploding Fist” was basically punch and kick.

The game offered an unprecedented sixteen karate moves, which allows for strategic game playing and complexity. Combinations of joystick directions (or keys on the keyboard) and the fire button (or SHIFT-key) make this game initially complicated to learn. However, once mastered, the controls are intuitive and become standard on single-button control systems. Designer and programmer Gregg Barnett practised all the movements as he developed it, mapping the combinations onto the joystick so that they felt fluid and natural.

The game allows for thumps, cracks and cries when you or your opponent is kicked effectively. Its sound design really bringing home the sense of the combat in contrast Neil Brennan‘s soundtrack offering an atmospheric sense of place. One of the most memorable features seems to be the intensive and high volume scream of ‘kai-ai ’ during the loading screen. made possible by Beam Softwares fast loader the Pav-Loada. The animation of the fighters is impressive, Beam’s artist Greg Holland cunningly dividing the body into two grids to support more complex animations. The quality of the graphics, including Japanese background imagery, adds to the overall essence of the game.

A review in “Crash” (issue 10, 1985, p12) says that “The Way of the Exploding Fist” ‘… is by far and away the best sports combat simulation available yet.’

[Source: Play It Again website: http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/the-way-of-the-exploding-fist-c64/
Last accessed: 13/8/2020]

results.title: H.U.R.G. for ZX Spectrum 48K
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer program. Cassette, manual, cardboard cassette case and plastic cassette tray.
results.brief_description:
“H.U.R.G., High-Level User-Friendly Real-Time Games Designer”, is a program that enables you to create games. It is a menu driven utility designed to assist in creating games for the ZX Spectrum 48K and can be used by those with little or no knowledge of programming. For example, by using the ‘Edit Game’ menu option, the player can select actions such as creating a title page or specifying playing conditions via sub-menus. Utilities like these opened the possibilities for using home computers, by making programming accessible to anyone who was interested. Games created with “H.U.R.G.” are not stand-alone; they still require the engine to run.

“H.U.R.G.” came with three demo games that were created within the engine: ‘Manic Koala’, ‘Egg Pack’ and ‘Ms. Hortense’. Melbourne House ran competitions to encourage people to use “H.U.R.G.” in games design, with cash prizes for the best games created on the software.

Source: Play It Again website:
http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/h-u-r-g-high-level-user-friendly-real-time-game-designer/

Last accessed: 5/05/2021

Original game developed by Beam Software. Published in 1984 by Melbourne House.

results.title: Zim Sala Bim for Commodore 64
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette, cardboard cassette case and plastic cassette tray.
results.brief_description: Zim Sala Bim [computer game]. Zim Sala Bim is a single player side scrolling graphical adventure game. The objective of the adventure is to break into the palace, steal the gold from the Sultan’s bedroom, get out and return to the secret cave and the village elders. Player are able to control the main character with either a joystick or keyboard keys through various environments. The character can be directed to perform various actions by typing two word commands made up of a verb followed by an action. A verb list is provided on the case. Results of player actions are given back as a text response. Items are scattered about the environment for players to retrieve and use.

results.title: Judge Dredd for ZX Spectrum 48/128
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette, cover, manual and plastic cassette case.
results.brief_description: Judge Dredd [computer game]. Judge Dredd is a single player action platformer. Players move Dredd to locations of crime as they appear on the sector map and select the crime they wish to pass judgement on. Once a crime has been selected, Dredd is dropped into a side scrolling platformer where both perps and civilians roam. Each crime is given an appropriate response level of Halt, Warn and Kill, though it is up to player discretion to change the response level. Depending on the response level is the action Dredd can perform, either shouting halt, firing warning shots or firing real bullets. Dredd can select a type of bullet from normal, armour piercing, incendiary, ricochet, high explosive and heat seeking.

results.title: Asterix and the Magic Cauldron for Spectrum 48/128
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette, cover and plastic cassette case.
results.brief_description:
Asterix and the Magic Cauldron is a single player adventure arcade game. Players control Asterix through various maps, collecting keys for locked doors and fighting Romans and boars in search of seven pieces of Getafix’s Magic Cauldron. Fights take place on a separate screen mode. Stamina bars for each combatant appear on the side of the window. Defeating the combatant adds it to the food tally. If Asterix loses the fight, the window closes and he loses a life. The same system is used when fighting the Roman soldiers and when Asterix picks up objects.

Obelix will only follow if Asterix has a supply of hams which can be obtained from fighting boars. Asterix starts with five lives and one dose of Magic Potion per game, which can be activated by double tapping the fire button.

Original game developed by Beam Software for ZX Spectrum 48K, published in 1986 by Melbourne House.

Source: Play It Again website: http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/asterix-and-the-magic-cauldron/

Last accessed: 1/05/2021

results.title: Asterix and the Magic Cauldron for Commodore 64/128
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette, cover, game manual and plastic cassette case.
results.brief_description:
Asterix and the Magic Cauldron is a single player adventure arcade game. Players control Asterix through various maps, collecting keys for locked doors and fighting Romans and boars in search of seven pieces of Getafix’s Magic Cauldron. Fights take place on a separate screen mode. Stamina bars for each combatant appear on the side of the window. Defeating the combatant adds it to the food tally. If Asterix loses the fight, the window closes and he loses a life. The same system is used when fighting the Roman soldiers and when Asterix picks up objects.

Obelix will only follow if Asterix has a supply of hams which can be obtained from fighting boars. Asterix starts with five lives and one dose of Magic Potion per game, which can be activated by double tapping the fire button.

Original game developed by Beam Software for ZX Spectrum 48K, published in 1986 by Melbourne House.

Source: Play It Again website: http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/asterix-and-the-magic-cauldron/

Last accessed: 1/05/2021

results.title: Knuckle Busters for Commodore 64/128
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette, cover and packing foam in a plastic cassette case.
results.brief_description: Knuckle Busters [computer game]. Knuckle Busters is a single player side scrolling action platformer. Players take on the role of Deke, a criminal escaping from a prision facility. Due to Deke’s tampering with the Central Computer, the facility and the city are expected to blow up, thus putting a time limit on the players. Players can jump and drop from platforms, avoid or fight androids, collect items and health from barrels and open doors. Deke’s condition is displayed to the player on a pop up menu including lives left, score, time count down, energy level and current object carried.

results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette, cover, badge and manual in a plastic cassette case.
results.brief_description: The Muncher [computer game]. The Muncher is a single player side scrolling action game. Players control a rampaging monster destroying buildings by climbing on them, breathing fire and jumping on people and cars while attempting to avoid getting shot at by people with guns. The game ends when the monster’s health has been depleted by being attacked.
